verses.text: One who keeps the law offers many sacrifices;
verses.comment: Sirach begins by emphasizing that obedience to God's commandments is as precious as making a multitude of sacrifices. This foreshadows Jesus' teaching on internal obedience over external ritual (see Matt. 9:13; Heb. 10:8-9).

verses.text: And one who heeds the commandments offers a peace offering.
verses.comment: Obedience is portrayed as a spiritual offering, echoing God's desire for a contrite heart over ritual alone (Ps. 51:16-17).

verses.text: One who returns kindness offers fine flour, and one who gives alms sacrifices a thank offering.
verses.comment: Giving alms is placed on par with temple sacrifices. Later Christian teaching upholds charity as a major aspect of true worship (see James 1:27; Acts 10:4).

verses.text: To turn away from evil is pleasing to the Lord, and to forsake injustice is an atonement.
verses.comment: Moral conversion is here described in sacrificial terms, prefiguring the New Testament's focus on repentance and inner change (see Luke 15:7; Rom. 12:1).

verses.text: Do not appear before the Lord empty-handed,
verses.comment: Participation in worship required offerings as a sign of devotion. This anticipation of giving oneself, not just material things, is deepened in Christian worship.

verses.text: for all these things are necessary as prescribed.
verses.comment: Faithful obedience to God's commands regarding offerings remains important, hinting at how appointed rituals later find fulfilment and transformation in the new covenant.

verses.text: The offering of the righteous enriches the altar, and its pleasing aroma rises before the Most High.
verses.comment: Sincere offerings, not mere performance, are desired by God. Paul uses similar language for spiritual sacrifices (cf. Heb. 13:15-16).

verses.text: The sacrifice of the righteous is acceptable, and it will not be forgotten.
verses.comment: God remembers acts of righteousness, a theme picked up by Jesus regarding rewards for charitable actions (see Matt. 10:42).

verses.text: Glorify the Lord generously, and do not be stingy in your firstfruits.
verses.comment: Offering the best to God in worship and charity reflects an inner disposition of generosity—a call deepened by Christ’s own self-giving.

verses.text: With every generous offering, let your face shine with gladness; dedicate your tithe with a joyful spirit.
verses.comment: Joyful giving is affirmed both in the Old and New Testaments, reminding believers that God loves a cheerful giver.

verses.text: Give to the Most High as he has given to you, and as generously as your hand has found.
verses.comment: God’s abundant generosity is the source and model for our own giving (cf. 1 John 4:19).

verses.text: For the Lord is one who repays, and he will pay you back sevenfold.
verses.comment: God’s faithfulness in rewarding acts of charity is affirmed by Christ (see Mark 10:30).

verses.text: Do not offer bribes, for he will not accept them; do not rely on an unjust sacrifice.
verses.comment: Sincerity of heart is preferred over ritualistic or transactional worship—a foundation for Christian teaching on purity of intention.

verses.text: The Lord is the judge, and with him there is no partiality.
verses.comment: God’s absolute justice is a strong Old and New Testament theme. See further in Acts 10:34.

verses.text: He will not show partiality against the poor, but he listens to the prayer of the oppressed.
verses.comment: God’s particular care for the poor foreshadows Jesus’ own preferential concern for the marginalized (Luke 4:18; 6:20).

verses.text: He will not ignore the cry of the orphan, nor the widow when she pours out her complaint.
verses.comment: God’s defense of orphans and widows transitions into the Church’s own mission of caritas and mercy (Acts 6:1-6).

verses.text: Do not the tears of the widow run down her cheek as she cries out against the one who has caused them?
verses.comment: God is attentive to those who suffer injustice, a principle foundational to biblical ethics.

verses.text: He whose service pleases the Lord will be accepted, and his supplication will reach the clouds.
verses.comment: This imagery is echoed in Revelation, where the prayers of the saints rise up to God like incense.

verses.text: The prayer of the humble pierces the clouds; it will not rest until it reaches the Lord. He will not desist until the Most High responds, judges righteously, and executes justice.
verses.comment: Persistent prayer and humility before God are here upheld, matching Christ’s parables on prayer.

verses.text: The Lord will not delay, nor will he be slow in defending them.
verses.comment: This verse reassures those who pray. Jesus promises similar speed in God’s answer to the elect (Luke 18:8).

verses.text: He will strike the loins of the unmerciful until he repays each according to his deeds,
verses.comment: God’s justice brings retribution upon the unjust, a warning echoed in the teaching of Jesus (Matt. 25:41-46).

verses.text: until he renders vengeance to the nations, breaks the power of the arrogant, and repays everyone according to their deeds.
verses.comment: The moral order is universal; God’s justice applies to all nations—fulfilled eschatologically in Christ’s second coming.

verses.text: He will show no partiality to princes, nor will he forgive the wicked for their wealth;
verses.comment: Both Old and New Testaments stress that status and riches cannot protect the unjust from God’s judgment.

verses.text: He listens to the prayer of the wronged,
verses.comment: God’s ear is turned especially to the suffering and those seeking righteousness.

verses.text: and does not forget the cry of the orphan, nor the widow when she pours out her complaint.
verses.comment: Another reaffirmation of God’s compassion, calling believers to visibly embody such mercy.

verses.text: Do the tears of the widow not run down her cheek as she cries out against the one who has caused them?
verses.comment: The chapter closes by again stressing God’s hearing of the afflicted, urging constant works of charity, mercy, and justice. In the Christian era, this takes fuller shape in the community’s shared life, prayer, and service—means by which grace and mercy reach the world.
